title: Best and Worst States to Retire Financially
subtitle: A Practical Guide to Choosing Your Retirement Location
content:
The Best and Worst States to Retire

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. Now I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Understand Total Cost

Before we get to the list, here's my only piece of advice: always look at the total cost, not just the income tax. According to Fidelity, a couple withdrawing $100,000 a year from their 401(k)s in high-tax Oregon pays a 12.98% effective tax rate. But in Iowa, it's only 7.66%. However, Oregon has no sales tax, while Iowa hits you at 7%. And remember, Florida's no income tax sounds great until your homeowner's insurance triples because of hurricanes.

2. The Worst States for Retirement

  • Hawaii
  • Washington D.C.
  • Minnesota

Interestingly, California and New York aren’t in the top five worst states. So if you're considering a panic retirement to a state based on its reputation rather than data, remember that Minnesota is quietly taxing your 401(k) at 9.85%—and nobody's noticing because they've got great hockey and stellar cheese curds.

3. The Best States for Retirement

There are 13 states that do not tax your 401(k) withdrawals at all. In retirement, that's huge:

  • Alaska
  • Florida
  • Illinois
  • Iowa
  • Mississippi
  • Nevada
  • New Hampshire
  • Pennsylvania
  • South Dakota
  • Tennessee
  • Texas
  • Washington
  • Wyoming

Iowa and Illinois are the hidden gems—no retirement income tax and lower total costs than Florida once you factor in insurance and property taxes.

Conclusion

If this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio. Each week, I'll send you over another money playbook that actually works.
